div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to [Wade Hampton Frost], October 20, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 20, 1928.

div1.p: Your letter of October 19th. just received.

(1): You are correct in assuming that Béranger-Féraud (Traité
théorique et clinique...(1890) p. 30, in citing Du Tertre re epidemic
St. Lucia (1665) gives no specific reference by volume or page, and
cites no authority other than Du Tertre. I hope that Miss Brown and
I can, eventually, get some satisfactory data on this reference, but,
of course, had not tried to do so up to the [unclear] quite recent time when I got
vol.iii of du Tertre. Prior to seeing his text, I had, of course,
expected to get a definite and satisfactory reference from him. Since,
however, you say that this reference can be disregarded if necessary,
I shall continue to concentrate on things more essential.

(2) By the way, (and merely as a matter of curiosity) re Lassis (ii. p. 57) :La Roche doesn't seem to
greatly admire him, stating (vol.ii. p. 70) “Especially, am I not
prepared to admit on so equivocal an authority as Lassis,” (who did
not share La Roche's views on contagion from what follows). LaRoche
apparently did not quote Lassis re epidemic Paris (1822), although he
gives his “Calamités”... (quoted by Augustin for this epidemic) in his
bibliography. As I wrote you before, none of Lassis' publications (I
only know of two, (ch. La Roche) are listed at any Library here.

(3) I am enclosing tentative library card re Book of the Jew, (iii.i.p. 60)
for which you have orange or pink bibliographic card. We got the ref-
erence by a fortunate accident, while looking up something else--which
we didn't get! Re this Book of the Jew, it can could only be seen by our
going to Boston or Philadelphia. Do you think it is important enough
for me to write both places to one of these places and ask for a trans-
-2-
transcription of the passage, or better yet, a photostat, containing
the prescription for “xekik”--“blood-vomit?” Of course, its just a
medical and literary curio, but it is a curio.

Miss Brown and I are working “very hard and very long,” as there
is still quite a lot to do at this end of the line. She's spending
the night with me as, to-morrow being Sunday, we can not only work
this evening, but get an early start in the morning. Lord! what a
mass of material Father read in connection with the book!--ever so much
more than we've been over, indeed, as we are only giving a bibliography
of author's mentioned in his work, and Father read many other books
which are not directly cited, indeed, took careful notes on some of
them.

Thank you very much for the biographic data, re Father, received
by special delivery last night. As you say, it can be so altered as
to leave out what is objectionable and misleading, which is the best
we can hope for it. I only trust the beastly thing hasn't gone to
press in its present form, as I'd hate to have the Nobel Prize and the
entire credit for the findings of the Reed Board bestowed on Father, after the MS had
been given me for correction!

Miss Brown and I str[unclear]aightened up a lot of long verbatim quota-
tions last night (in the bound I. H. B. books). Its slow work, but
I'll send them back as soon as I can. Just got Mendieta's Historia
Eclesiastica Indiana (for Section iii, part i--the Americas) the other
day (its been lost) and we started verifying its refs. this A. M.

Hoping you've had a pleasant week-end, [unclear] plenty of golf (in al-
most as good company as you yourself afforded!) a good rest, and “lurid
literature” enough to make you forget your editorial labors,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Love to the Suaans.
L.
